Description: Neck and shoulder sherd of Attic black-figured pottery column-krater; interior: glazed streaky black; exterior: neck glazed; chequer pattern at top of shoulder; below, from left: part of two horses’ heads to right; near horse’s head lowered with ear, mane and forelock remaining (added red on eye and forelocks of both); head of hoplite wearing Corinthian helmet to right, spear at angle on his left (red on spear and helmet); facing him an archer (nose, lips, beard and part of cap remaining); between them is a dot rosette.
Producer name: Manner/Style of: The KY Painter (Komast Group)
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.599.b and 1888,0601.599.c (from side B); another fragment from side B is Oxford AN1896-1908-G.128.18. For early Attic column kraters, see Payne, H., Necrocorinthia. Oxford 1931, nos 16-22.
Bibliographic references: Beazley & Payne 1929 / Attic Black Figured Fragments from Naukratis (p. 256, no. 12)
Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (p. 195-7, no. 35)
Beazley 1944 / Groups of Early Attic Black Figure (p. 48, no. 2)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 261, no. B182)
Venit 1984 / Early Attic Black Figure Vases in Egypt (p. 147, note 43/14)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 228, no. 15)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0127) (Phase 1)
Alexandridou 2011 / The Early Black-Figured Pottery of Attika in Context (c. 630-570BCE) (p. 123) (Naurkatis 100)
